ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the significance of diversity in STEM.
Components of writing an Op-Ed, developing an intervention project.
I gained a deeper knowledge of the state of diversity in STEM, the people affected, and how a negative environment can be detrimental to those with intersectional personalities.

I learned so much about the nuances of the experiences of underrepresented groups, and about what can be done to alleviate and facilitate the experiences of those students. Despite how STEM can seem like a very unwelcoming field, particularly in the physical sciences, it really doesnt have to be.

We analyzed underrepresentation in STEM from different angles, both in terms of accessibility for POC, women, people with disabilities, people who identify as LGBTQ+, and how stereotype threat, opportunity hoarding, imposter syndrome, implicit bias, financial stressors, representation etc. impacts hiring practices, retention, salaries, admissions, discrimination, belonging.
This class was a great way to learn about others' experiences in STEM and the systemic problems different groups face in science. Very eye-opening and interesting.

I learned about the plights of different demographics in the STEM world and in higher academia in general. There were readings about students of color, LGBTQ+ students, students with disabilities, low-income and first-generation students, and more. I developed a better understanding of the challenges I have faced and other students face that often go unnoticed. I also learned how to begin to combat some of these barriers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was heavily focused on a discussion of diversity. While this is a super important topic I felt like the class was an echo chamber at times, because everyone already had the same general opinions.
I really enjoyed the atmosphere of the class and the professors. Also the project was fun and interesting.

Strengths: light workload, interesting conversations, lots of time to dedicate to the final project. Weaknesses: would have liked to see more diversity amongst the instructor team, or invite guest speakers from different backgrounds.

I thought the strength of the course was it's multi-professor format. I appreciated our candid discussions but wish the class focused even more on discussion. I also thought that sometimes it was difficult to express a different opinion for fear of reprisal.

The readings are amazing, but at times it felt like they were a bit too long. Especially when the semester ramped up, despite wanting to engage with the readings, it was difficult, as there was a lot to read.

I think a strength is the opportunity given to students to explore topics they care about such as the Other Voices project where students pick topics and get to create a 30 minute lesson plan. This genuinely gave an opportunity to learn about topics we never really discuss such as the difficulties of undocumented students in education/STEM, traditional ecological knowledge from indigenous people, imposter syndrome in grad school etc. Another strength is the head professors who really cared. I also enjoyed learning how to write an Op-Ed. The weaknesses is the overlap between a lot of assignments. We had weekly comments/reading, reflections, along with essay deadlines, other voices deadlines, and the group project deadlines that would fall on the same day. In the future, it would be nice to decrease the weekly comments/readings. I would also recommend eliminating the reflections altogether. It just feels like busy work and doesn't actually improve knowledge or thinking. It's purpose was stated to be to have people think in advance for class discussion but it really doesn't help as all you do is regurgitate what you read 5 minutes ago and forget after.

This class lead to excellent discussions and addressed a broad range of issues in a holistic, sensitive, and open-minded way. The only problem I found with this class were the reflections after each and every assignment, even if we just completed a huge project and gave a presentation, we would have to repeat everything we said in a reflection. These reflections might be useful for the professors, but I thought they were sometimes unnecessary busywork.

Discussion is at the core of this course, and as a result the time allotted for discussion was a strength. We got to discuss the papers at our own rate with students and professors alike. After the introducing questions the class just focused on discussing the interesting aspects of the papers which I enjoyed. A weakness could be needing more support for the project that we take on in the second half of the semester. It was a lot more work than we were led to believe at first, but the projects did differ in time commitment and that wasn't so clear.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was still good during COVID-19, but the project aspect was a bit harder to complete.
Discussions worked well on Zoom.

The Zoom classes were well facilitated for sure. However, one thing I disliked is the lack of divide between class and non-class hours where we would get surprise emails about discussion section etc. outside of class hours which would be another thing for us to think about/do. It isn't that what we were asked to do is super hard, it's about the fact it would usually have to do with group work which then meant we had to meet or discuss as a group to get consensus which isn't easy with our weird schedules during COVID. In the future, I would just recommend delaying it to the next time you actually see the class.
This class was great over Zoom, I have nothing to add here

The platform we used for readings was new to the course and it is called Perusall. Students would annotate and comment on the readings and those notes were accessible to the entire class which I thought was a neat feature that came from having to be a virtual course. This increased my own engagement in the content we were reading as I could see in real time what people thought about it.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to discuss diversity in STEM.
Yes - all the professors were great and the discussions were important

Yes, there are very few STEM classes that give you the opportunity to reflect on issues presented in class. You also are able to take actionable steps to address diversity and inclusion problems in STEM through the final project.
Yes, take this course! The teaching staff are amazing!

100%, except if you already have a high workload semester. This class is amazing and extremely engaging, but it will take time and dedication to get what you have to get done, done. Especially with the intervention project, the class can take a lot of time. However, the content we go through in the course is SO valuable.

Definitely, if you have an interest in learning about difficulties in making STEM accessible take the course. You should also take the course if you want to actively contribute to changing the STEM atmosphere at Yale through the actionable group project.

I would recommend this course to underclassmen interested in learning more about social justice within STEM. If you already have a background in this subject, some of the information may be a bit redundant -- but the discussions are still great, and you really get to know your classmates!
Yes! I think this should be a required class for STEM majors. It's so important to make an effort to understand others' experiences, especially in regards to big systemic issues.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially to STEM students although it shouldn't be limited to that demographic. This course covered content that explains why STEM looks and operates the way it does right now which is fundamentally inaccessible. This knowledge is important to learn if you plan to be in STEM. The course was also not a huge time commitment although the workload does pick up a bit toward the end of the semester. Please take it!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: + virtual discussion section
The course itself was in a discussion/seminar format, and in addition to class time we had to meet with the teaching assistant for an additional hour which was more of a work time.
